articles.title: Secretary-General on UN at 80: Humanity strongest when we stand as one
articles.summary: Powerful forces are lining up to undermine global cooperation, United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres warned at a landmark event in London on Saturday to commemorate the 80th anniversary of the General Assembly, but he urged that “humanity is strongest when we stand as one”.
articles.content:
Speaking at Methodist Central Hall, the very same venue where the first-ever UN General Assembly was held on 10 January 1946, Mr. Guterres called on delegates at the event to be “bold enough to change. Bold enough to find the courage of those who came to this Hall 80 years ago to forge a better world.”

Tweet URL

From bomb shelter to diplomatic gathering

Organised by the United Nations Association-UK, Saturday's anniversary event gathered over 1,000 delegates from across the world, with speakers including President of the General Assembly, Annalena Baerbock, the UN Champion for Space Professor Brian Cox and the UN Refugee Agency’s Goodwill Ambassador Maya Ghazal. The event also marks the 80th anniversary of the first UN Security Council, which took place on 17 January 1946 at nearby Church House.

During his keynote address, Mr. Guterres reflected on the symbolic location of the commemoration. The first General Assembly took place within the same walls four months after the end of the Second World War, in a heavily bombed London where tens of thousands had been killed, a powerful reminder as to why the UN had been created.

“To reach this Hall, delegates had to pass through a city scarred by war. Buckingham Palace, Westminster Abbey, and the House of Commons had been shelled by the Luftwaffe. And as those bombs fell, terrified civilians huddled here, in the basement of the Methodist Central Hall — one of the largest public air-raid shelters in London,” said the Secretary-General.

Throughout the Blitz, as many as 2,000 people gathered in the hall for protection, before the nations of the world assembled there in 1946 to ‘save succeeding generations from the scourge of war’.

“In many ways, this Hall is a physical representation of what the United Nations is: a place people put their faith — for peace, for security, for a better life,” reflected Mr. Guterres.

The world of 2026 is not the world of 1946

In the 80 years since the first General Assembly, the UN has expanded from 51 members to 193. Mr. Guterres emphasised that the General Assembly, the UN’s chief deliberative, policymaking and representative body, is “the parliament of the family of nations. It is a forum for every voice to be heard, a crucible for consensus, and a beacon for cooperation.”

Whilst he acknowledged that the General Assembly’s work “may not always be straightforward or seamless,” he described it as a “a mirror of our world, its divisions and its hopes. And it is the stage on which our shared story plays out.”

Reflecting on the last decade, Mr. Guterres spoke of how “the conflicts in Gaza, Ukraine and Sudan have been vicious and cruel beyond measure; artificial intelligence has become ubiquitous almost overnight; and the pandemic poured accelerant on the fires of nationalism — stalling progress on development and climate action.”

Mr. Guterres emphasised how 2025 was a “profoundly challenging” year for international cooperation and the UN’s values.

“Aid was slashed. Inequalities widened. Climate chaos accelerated. International law was trampled. Crackdowns on civil society intensified. Journalists were killed with impunity. And United Nations staff were repeatedly threatened — or killed — in the line of duty.”

The UN reported in 2025 that global military spending reached $2.7 trillion — over 200 times the UK’s current aid budget, or equivalent to over 70 per cent of Britain’s entire economy.

Fossil fuel profits have also continued to surge whilst the planet broke heat records, Mr. Guterres underlined.

“And in cyberspace, algorithms rewarded falsehoods, fuelled hatred, and provided authoritarians with powerful tools of control.”

Multilateralism over division

A “robust, responsive and well-resourced multilateral” system is needed to address the world’s interconnected challenges, Mr. Guterres urged, but the “values of multilateralism are being chipped away.”

The Secretary-General gave the example of a landmark international agreement to protect marine life in international waters and the seabed, which comes into force on Saturday, as a “model of modern diplomacy, led by science, with the participation not just of governments, but of civil society, Indigenous Peoples and local communities.”

“These quiet victories of international cooperation — the wars prevented, the famine averted, the vital treaties secured — do not always make the headlines. Yet they are real. And they matter. If we wish to secure more such victories, we must ensure the full respect of international law and defend multilateralism, strengthening it for our times.”

As he addressed the London audience, the Secretary-General expressed his “gratitude to the United Kingdom for its decisive role in creating the United Nations,” and for being “such a strong pillar of multilateralism and champion of the United Nations today.”

© United Nations/Shaun Ottway UN Secretary-General António Guterres (right) met with UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer at 10 Downing Street in London on Friday.

High stakes for a better world

Looking towards the future, the Secretary-General called for an international system that reflects the modern world, including reforming international financial systems and the Security Council.

“As global centres of power shift, we have the potential to build a future that is either more fair — or more unstable.”

The Secretary-General reminded delegates in London that when the UN first opened its doors, “many of its staff bore the visible wounds of war — a limp, a scar, a burn.”

“There is a persistent myth — now echoing louder each day — that peace is naïve. That the only ‘real’ politics is the politics of self-interest and force,” Mr. Guterres said.

“But the founders of the United Nations were not untouched by reality. On the contrary, they had seen war, and they knew: Peace, justice and equality, are the most courageous, the most practical, the most necessary pursuits of all.”

*Miranda Alexander-Webber is a communications officer with the United Nations Regional Information Centre for Western Europe (UNRIC).

articles.personality_title: UN Secretary-General urges united action as UN marks 80 years
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The United Nations (UN) was created in 1945 after World War II to help countries work together for peace and security. This year, the UN’s General Assembly, where all member countries meet, celebrated its 80th anniversary at the same London hall where it first gathered in 1946.

**What happened** – At a special event in London, UN Secretary-General António Guterres spoke about the ongoing challenges facing global cooperation. He reminded attendees that the UN was born from the hope to prevent war and promote peace. Over 1,000 delegates, including leaders and ambassadors, gathered to mark this milestone and discuss the future of international teamwork.

**Impact** – Guterres highlighted serious issues like conflicts in places such as Gaza and Ukraine, rising inequality, climate change, and misinformation online. Despite these problems, he pointed to recent successes like a new international agreement to protect marine life as examples of how countries can work together. His message stressed that the UN remains a key place for solving global problems through cooperation and respect for international law.

**What's next step** – The Secretary-General called for reforms to make the UN and its financial and security systems better suited for today’s world. He urged countries to strengthen multilateralism, meaning working together through international organizations, to face future challenges fairly and peacefully.

**One-sentence takeaway** – As the UN celebrates 80 years, its leader emphasizes that global peace and progress depend on countries standing united and reforming international cooperation to meet today’s challenges.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Secrétaire général de l’ONU appelle à l’unité à l’occasion des 80 ans de l’ONU
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Organisation des Nations Unies (ONU) a été créée en 1945 après la Seconde Guerre mondiale pour aider les pays à travailler ensemble pour la paix et la sécurité. Cette année, l’Assemblée générale de l’ONU, où tous les États membres se réunissent, a célébré son 80e anniversaire dans la même salle de Londres où elle s’est tenue pour la première fois en 1946.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors d’un événement spécial à Londres, le Secrétaire général de l’ONU, António Guterres, a parlé des défis actuels pour la coopération mondiale. Il a rappelé aux participants que l’ONU est née de l’espoir d’éviter la guerre et de promouvoir la paix. Plus de 1 000 délégués, dont des dirigeants et des ambassadeurs, se sont réunis pour marquer cet anniversaire et discuter de l’avenir du travail international.

**Impact** – M. Guterres a souligné des problèmes graves comme les conflits à Gaza et en Ukraine, les inégalités croissantes, le changement climatique et la désinformation en ligne. Malgré ces difficultés, il a cité des réussites récentes comme un nouvel accord international pour protéger la vie marine, montrant que les pays peuvent coopérer. Son message a insisté sur le fait que l’ONU reste un lieu clé pour résoudre les problèmes mondiaux grâce à la coopération et au respect du droit international.

**La prochaine étape** – Le Secrétaire général a appelé à des réformes pour adapter l’ONU et ses systèmes financiers et de sécurité au monde d’aujourd’hui. Il a exhorté les pays à renforcer le multilatéralisme, c’est-à-dire travailler ensemble via des organisations internationales, pour relever les défis futurs de manière juste et pacifique.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Alors que l’ONU fête ses 80 ans, son leader souligne que la paix et le progrès mondiaux dépendent de l’unité des pays et de la réforme de la coopération internationale pour relever les défis actuels.

Más de 1,000 delegados, incluidos líderes y embajadores, se reunieron para celebrar este aniversario y hablar sobre el futuro del trabajo internacional.

articles.title: Šefčovič: As with CETA, there is no need to worry about the trade agreement with the Mercosur countries
articles.summary: European Commissioner for Trade Maroš Šefčovič, after visiting Cyprus, recalled that Europeans had concerns about the CETA agreement, just as they do now about the agreement with MERCOSUR.
articles.content:
European Commissioner for Trade Maroš Šefčovič, after visiting Cyprus, recalled that Europeans had concerns about the CETA agreement, just as they do now about the agreement with MERCOSUR.

Limassol – The free trade agreement with the Mercosur countries continues to raise concerns and criticism from the member states of the European Union (EU) and farmers, but there is no need to fear it. EU Commissioner for Trade and Economic Security Maroš Šefčovič stated this for TASR.

Maroš Šefčovič on Thursday (15 January) – before Friday’s departure for Paraguay, where he is accompanying the President of the European Commission (EC) Ursula von der Leyen and the President of the European Council Antonio Costa, who will sign the agreement with the Mercosur countries on behalf of the EU – took part in a joint meeting of the College of Commissioners with members of the Cypriot government in the Cypriot port of Limassol.

He welcomed the fact that the Cypriot Presidency of the Council of the EU on 9 January secured a vote in which a qualified majority of member countries supported the agreement with Mercosur. After it is signed in Paraguay, the same process awaits this agreement in the European Parliament and subsequently Cyprus will be responsible for ensuring its ratification by the member states as quickly as possible.

Šefčovič recalled that the EU has already experienced a similar situation when approving the trade agreement with Canada (CETA).

“Canada is the latest example where the conclusion of the agreement was also preceded by very intense discussion, and the concerns of the food industry community were very strong. Today, eight years after its conclusion, there is absolute satisfaction, also because mutual trade has increased by 60 percent,” he explained.

He added that none of the negative scenarios materialised in the case of CETA. The agreement is advantageous for farmers, for engineers, and it significantly helps both the European and Canadian economies.

“The agreement with Mercosur also contains sufficiently strong guarantees, both financial and administrative. Let’s say that farmers will not be endangered. The mechanisms that the European Commission proposed for their protection were approved in the European Parliament,” he pointed out.

According to him, the EC approached this agreement with exceptional sensitivity. All import quotas in the area of sensitive commodities such as beef, ethanol or chicken meat were carefully set. Under no circumstances can they pose a threat to European farmers.

“At the same time, we have introduced unprecedented legal guarantees that provide such protection for European farmers that if imports from Mercosur countries were to rise by five percent or if the price of these sensitive commodities were to jump by five percent on the European market, then the European Commission would have to intervene. It can apply emergency brakes. All specific measures to protect farmers were summarised in a European regulation, the strongest legal instrument the EU has at its disposal,” he described the situation.

The Commission is also continuing to work on aligning procedures in the area of pesticide use, in the area of animal welfare, on increasing controls through European veterinary audits of goods from Mercosur countries, as well as in the main points of import, which are European ports and airports.

“Everything possible has been done to ensure that products and commodities imported into Europe from these countries meet the most demanding European criteria. As an additional safeguard, a financial guarantee was approved in the form of a so‑called safety net for farmers amounting to 6.3 billion euros. I consider this a kind of insurance,” said Šefčovič. And he expressed his conviction that, just as in the case of Canada, there will be no negative trends in the implementation of the agreements with Mercosur and that everyone will be pleasantly surprised by the significant impact this will have on the economies of the Mercosur countries and the EU countries. (16 January)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the EU-Mercosur trade agreement which, like the earlier EU-Canada CETA agreement, is expected to bring significant economic benefits and protections to farmers and industries on both sides. It highlights strong legal safeguards, financial guarantees, and regulatory measures to protect sensitive sectors, indicating a positive real-world impact with broad significance for multiple countries and their economies. The detailed context and comparison to a successful precedent add substance to the story.
articles.personality_title: EU trade commissioner reassures on Mercosur deal, citing CETA success
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) is preparing to finalize a free trade agreement with the Mercosur countries, which include Brazil, Argentina, Uruguay, and Paraguay. Some EU member states and farmers have expressed worries about the deal’s effects, similar to past concerns about a trade deal with Canada called CETA.

**What happened** – Maroš Šefčovič, the EU Commissioner for Trade and Economic Security, spoke after visiting Cyprus and before traveling to Paraguay, where the Mercosur agreement will be signed. He highlighted that the EU has already faced similar fears with CETA, but over time, the trade deal brought benefits without the feared problems. The Mercosur agreement includes strong rules to protect European farmers and industries, such as limits on sensitive imports and a financial safety net of 6.3 billion euros.

**Impact** – This agreement is important because it aims to increase trade between the EU and Mercosur countries while protecting local farmers and industries from sudden market changes. For example, if imports rise too much or prices change drastically, the EU can quickly act to protect its markets. The deal also ensures that products meet strict European standards on food safety and animal welfare, which helps maintain quality and trust.

**What's next step** – After signing in Paraguay, the agreement will be reviewed and must be approved by the European Parliament and EU member states. Cyprus will lead the effort to complete this approval quickly. If successful, the deal will boost trade and economic growth on both sides, similar to what happened with the Canada-EU CETA agreement.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The EU’s trade agreement with Mercosur includes strong protections and financial safeguards, promising benefits for farmers and economies based on past experience with the CETA deal.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le commissaire européen rassure sur l’accord Mercosur en citant le succès du CETA
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne (UE) s’apprête à finaliser un accord de libre-échange avec les pays du Mercosur, qui comprennent le Brésil, l’Argentine, l’Uruguay et le Paraguay. Certains États membres de l’UE et des agriculteurs s’inquiètent des effets de cet accord, comme cela avait été le cas pour un accord commercial avec le Canada appelé CETA.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Maroš Šefčovič, commissaire européen au commerce et à la sécurité économique, s’est exprimé après sa visite à Chypre et avant de se rendre au Paraguay, où l’accord Mercosur sera signé. Il a souligné que l’UE avait déjà fait face à des craintes similaires avec le CETA, mais qu’avec le temps, cet accord avait apporté des bénéfices sans les problèmes redoutés. L’accord Mercosur comprend des règles strictes pour protéger les agriculteurs et les industries européennes, comme des limites sur les importations sensibles et un filet de sécurité financier de 6,3 milliards d’euros.

**Impact** – Cet accord est important car il vise à augmenter les échanges entre l’UE et les pays du Mercosur tout en protégeant les agriculteurs et industries locaux contre des changements soudains du marché. Par exemple, si les importations augmentent trop ou si les prix changent fortement, l’UE peut agir rapidement pour protéger ses marchés. L’accord garantit aussi que les produits respectent des normes européennes strictes en matière de sécurité alimentaire et de bien-être animal, ce qui aide à maintenir la qualité et la confiance.

**Prochaine étape** – Après la signature au Paraguay, l’accord sera examiné et doit être approuvé par le Parlement européen et les États membres de l’UE. Chypre prendra la tête de cet effort pour finaliser rapidement cette approbation. En cas de succès, l’accord stimulera le commerce et la croissance économique des deux côtés, comme cela s’est produit avec l’accord CETA entre le Canada et l’UE.

**Résumé en une phrase** – L’accord commercial de l’UE avec le Mercosur inclut de fortes protections et garanties financières, promettant des bénéfices pour les agriculteurs et les économies, sur la base de l’expérience passée avec le CETA.
articles.personality_title_es: El comisario de la UE tranquiliza sobre el acuerdo Mercosur citando el éxito del CETA
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) se está preparando para finalizar un acuerdo de libre comercio con los países del Mercosur, que incluyen Brasil, Argentina, Uruguay y Paraguay. Algunos estados miembros de la UE y agricultores han expresado preocupaciones sobre los efectos del acuerdo, similares a las preocupaciones anteriores sobre un acuerdo comercial con Canadá llamado CETA.

**Qué pasó** – Maroš Šefčovič, comisario de comercio y seguridad económica de la UE, habló después de visitar Chipre y antes de viajar a Paraguay, donde se firmará el acuerdo Mercosur. Destacó que la UE ya enfrentó temores similares con el CETA, pero con el tiempo, ese acuerdo comercial trajo beneficios sin los problemas temidos. El acuerdo Mercosur incluye reglas fuertes para proteger a los agricultores e industrias europeas, como límites en importaciones sensibles y una red de seguridad financiera de 6,3 mil millones de euros.

**Impacto** – Este acuerdo es importante porque busca aumentar el comercio entre la UE y los países del Mercosur mientras protege a los agricultores e industrias locales de cambios repentinos en el mercado. Por ejemplo, si las importaciones aumentan demasiado o los precios cambian mucho, la UE puede actuar rápidamente para proteger sus mercados. El acuerdo también asegura que los productos cumplan con estrictos estándares europeos de seguridad alimentaria y bienestar animal, lo que ayuda a mantener la calidad y la confianza.

**Próximo paso** – Después de la firma en Paraguay, el acuerdo será revisado y debe ser aprobado por el Parlamento Europeo y los estados miembros de la UE. Chipre liderará el esfuerzo para completar esta aprobación rápidamente. Si tiene éxito, el acuerdo impulsará el comercio y el crecimiento económico en ambos lados, similar a lo ocurrido con el acuerdo CETA entre Canadá y la UE.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El acuerdo comercial de la UE con Mercosur incluye fuertes protecciones y garantías financieras, prometiendo beneficios para agricultores y economías basados en la experiencia pasada con el acuerdo CETA.

articles.title: During the course of my PhD, I’ve been relearning how to rest
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 15 January 2026; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03342-8Small acts of change have helped me to reset and give myself a break.
articles.content:
People with PhDs say they spent years during their studies feeling exhausted and lost their work–life balance. Credit: Getty

I have just started the fourth year of my PhD. As I reflect on where the time has gone, I realize that my mental health is not where I want it to be.

I’ve been fortunate to have a supportive adviser and an incredible laboratory environment at Stanford University in California — that includes some of the most wonderful people I’ve ever worked with. But even with that, there’s a broader academic culture that seeps into the habits of many researchers — one that rewards burnout and discourages rest.

Somewhere along the way, I started wearing burnout like a badge of honour. In weekly lab check-ins, I make sure to mention I was in the lab over the weekend — slipping in a quiet signal that I was going above and beyond. I’ve made sure to send e-mails early in the morning or late at night to demonstrate I was working long hours.

I’m exhausted. Doesn’t that mean I’m doing something right?

It wasn’t until my mother visited me in July that something shifted. She stayed with me for a few days, and although we spent time together — walking outside, catching up over dinner — she noticed I wasn’t really ‘there’ in the moment. I looked pale, she told my partner later. She could see that the PhD journey was taking a toll on me.

This list of non-negotiables helped me to defeat PhD-student guilt

After she left, I talked to a lab mate about it. I said I was trying to find my equilibrium again. My lab mate said, “You’re taking a step away. I’m so excited for you.”

I immediately got defensive. “I’m not slacking,” I said. “I’m not falling behind!” This culture of burnout can be especially difficult for students, including myself, who don’t plan to pursue a career in academia. When academic work is exhausting and your research is meant to receive your all, it leaves little time for other necessities, such as career exploration, hobbies and socializing — all of which are essential for a career and a life beyond the lab.

That’s part of why I started PhD Paths a little over a year ago, an extracurricular project for which I’ve interviewed 300 PhD holders who’ve transitioned to careers beyond academia. I share their written interviews by means of a Google Sheets database, website and newsletter. It began as a personal attempt to explore what other career avenues were possible, after realizing that I did not want to stay in academia. PhD Paths has grown into a community of thousands of readers and contributors, challenging the narrative that there’s only one ‘successful’ path for PhD students.

Using these interviews, I share the stories of those who’ve gone before — to show the diverse career opportunities that a PhD can lead to, and to remind others that they’re not alone.

I ask each interviewee: “Why did you decide to not pursue a career in academia?” The most common reason was the culture of the academic world. In fact, more than half of the people I interviewed said that some component of the academic culture drove them away. They described poor work–life balance, relentless pressure to publish and an undercurrent of stress that never let up.

The exhaustion identity

In academia, there’s a curious ritual when someone asks, “How are you?” The correct answer is never “great” or “well-rested”. It’s “busy” or “exhausted”. The idea being that, if you’re not tired, you’re not working hard enough. As a scientist, I’ve tied my identity to exhaustion.

Through these conversations, I’ve learnt that my experience isn’t unusual. Again and again, interviewees have told me that they spent years during their PhD studies feeling exhausted, from working too many hours, and had lost their work–life balance. They were amazed at the flexibility and minimal stress that they experienced when they stepped out of academia and into an industry position.

That’s why I’ve shared these stories beyond my own circle. What began with two viral posts that introduced the PhD Paths resource — which together reached more than one million impressions on LinkedIn — has grown into a personal audience of more than 24,000 followers on the social-media platform, as well as a PhD Paths newsletter reaching more than 7,000 readers.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights a positive cultural shift addressing mental health and work-life balance issues in academia, a significant societal challenge affecting many researchers globally. It promotes awareness and community support through the PhD Paths project, offering alternative career perspectives and reducing stigma around burnout. This has broad relevance and tangible benefits for the wellbeing and career satisfaction of a large population of PhD students and holders.
articles.personality_title: PhD student creates community to fight burnout and explore new career paths
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many PhD students feel very tired and stressed during their studies because of long hours and pressure to succeed. This often leads to losing balance between work and personal life.

**What happened** – A PhD student at Stanford University started a project called PhD Paths after realizing the toll the academic culture took on her mental health. She interviewed 300 PhD holders who chose careers outside academia and shared their stories through a website, newsletter, and social media.

**Impact** – The project helps PhD students see that there are many career options beyond the traditional academic route. It also challenges the idea that being exhausted means you are working hard enough. Thousands of people now follow her work, finding support and new ideas for their futures.

articles.personality_title_fr: Une doctorante crée une communauté pour lutter contre l'épuisement et explorer de nouvelles carrières
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Beaucoup d’étudiants en doctorat se sentent très fatigués et stressés à cause des longues heures de travail et de la pression pour réussir. Cela entraîne souvent une perte d’équilibre entre vie professionnelle et personnelle.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une doctorante de l’université de Stanford a lancé un projet appelé PhD Paths après avoir constaté l’impact de la culture académique sur sa santé mentale. Elle a interviewé 300 titulaires de doctorat ayant choisi des carrières hors du milieu universitaire et a partagé leurs histoires via un site web, une newsletter et les réseaux sociaux.

**Impact** – Ce projet aide les doctorants à découvrir qu’il existe de nombreuses options de carrière au-delà de la voie académique traditionnelle. Il remet aussi en question l’idée que l’épuisement signifie qu’on travaille suffisamment dur. Des milliers de personnes suivent désormais son travail, trouvant soutien et nouvelles idées pour leur avenir.

**Prochaine étape** – PhD Paths va continuer à développer sa communauté et ses ressources, encourageant plus d’étudiants et diplômés à adopter des habitudes de travail saines et à explorer des carrières variées en dehors des laboratoires.

**Phrase clé** – Le projet d’une doctorante change la façon dont les chercheurs perçoivent le travail, le repos et les choix de carrière en partageant des histoires vraies et en créant une communauté solidaire.
articles.personality_title_es: Una estudiante de doctorado crea comunidad para combatir el agotamiento y explorar nuevas carreras
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Muchos estudiantes de doctorado se sienten muy cansados y estresados por las largas horas y la presión para tener éxito. Esto a menudo provoca perder el equilibrio entre el trabajo y la vida personal.

**Qué pasó** – Una estudiante de doctorado en la Universidad de Stanford inició un proyecto llamado PhD Paths tras darse cuenta del impacto de la cultura académica en su salud mental. Entrevistó a 300 doctores que eligieron carreras fuera del mundo académico y compartió sus historias mediante un sitio web, boletín y redes sociales.

**Impacto** – El proyecto ayuda a los estudiantes de doctorado a ver que existen muchas opciones de carrera más allá del camino académico tradicional. También cuestiona la idea de que estar agotado significa que se está trabajando lo suficiente. Miles de personas ahora siguen su trabajo, encontrando apoyo y nuevas ideas para su futuro.

**Próximo paso** – PhD Paths seguirá creciendo su comunidad y recursos, animando a más estudiantes y graduados a adoptar hábitos de trabajo saludables y explorar carreras diversas fuera de los laboratorios.

**Frase clave** – El proyecto de una estudiante de doctorado está cambiando cómo los investigadores piensan sobre el trabajo, el descanso y las elecciones profesionales al compartir historias reales y construir una comunidad de apoyo.

articles.title: Šefčovič: The Cypriot Presidency accommodates the EU’s trade policy
articles.summary: EU Commissioner for Trade Maroš Šefčovič, during his visit to Cyprus, praised the support of the Cypriot Presidency of the Council of the EU for the EC's trade policy.
articles.content:
EU Commissioner for Trade Maroš Šefčovič, during his visit to Cyprus, praised the support of the Cypriot Presidency of the Council of the EU for the EC’s trade policy.

Limassol – The Cypriot Presidency of the Council of the European Union (EU) is willing to help the European Commission (EC) in achieving its trade and economic objectives. EU Commissioner for Trade and Economic Security Maroš Šefčovič stated this for TASR’s correspondent on Thursday after a joint meeting of the College of Commissioners with members of the Cypriot government, chaired by EC President Ursula von der Leyen and Cypriot President Nikos Christodoulides in Limassol.

Maroš Šefčovič expressed satisfaction that the European Commission and the incoming Cypriot Presidency agree on two fundamental priorities. First and foremost, this concerns European economic security, where concrete steps must be taken to ensure this security, whether through better information sharing between Member States and EU institutions or through the creation of a European network of national advisers for economic security.

“And then, of course, there are negotiations with our trading partners. On the one hand, cooperation on completing the ratification of the agreement with the Mercosur countries, which is to be signed this weekend; then, of course, there is great interest in concluding the agreement with India, but it is also about speeding up negotiations with the Gulf countries, since Cyprus knows this geographical area very well,” Šefčovič explained.

He confirmed that the EC will also need the help of the Cypriot Presidency to speed up the ratification of the trade agreement with Mexico, because it is a very important global player in terms of imports of food and agricultural commodities.

In April, the Cypriot Presidency will prepare an extraordinary summit focused on the Mediterranean agreement, to which it will invite leaders from the Middle East and North Africa. The Cypriot president emphasized the importance of the summit for strengthening not only security and migration interests, but also the Union’s trade relations.

“We in the European Commission believe that for cooperation between countries and for businesses it is better if barriers are reduced, and not the other way around, if we operate in a space that is clearly defined by internationally recognized rules and with respect for international trade law,” Šefčovič said. He added that the EC therefore supports every activity that would lead to reducing barriers and to mutually beneficial trade in the sense that it will also increase opportunities for European producers and traders to open new contacts and business relations. (15 January)
articles.reasoning: The article reports on the Cypriot Presidency's support for the EU's trade policy aimed at enhancing economic security and fostering international trade agreements. These efforts have broad significance for economic stability and cooperation across multiple regions, potentially benefiting many people through reduced trade barriers and stronger economic ties. The article provides detailed context on specific trade negotiations and upcoming summits, showing substantive progress and commitment.
articles.personality_title: Cyprus supports EU trade efforts to boost security and global partnerships
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The European Union (EU) works with different countries to create trade agreements that help businesses and improve economic security. The Cypriot Presidency of the EU Council is a leadership role held by Cyprus to guide EU decisions for six months.

**What happened** – During a visit to Cyprus, Maroš Šefčovič, the EU Commissioner for Trade and Economic Security, praised Cyprus for supporting the EU’s trade policies. At a meeting in Limassol, Cyprus agreed to help the European Commission (EC) with important trade goals. These include finalizing agreements with countries like Mercosur (a group of South American nations), India, the Gulf countries, and Mexico.

**Impact** – This cooperation is important because it aims to reduce trade barriers and improve economic security for EU countries. By working closely with Cyprus, the EU hopes to create safer and stronger trade relationships that allow European businesses to grow and connect with new partners. The planned summit in April will bring leaders from the Mediterranean region to discuss trade, security, and migration, showing a broad effort to strengthen ties beyond Europe.

**What's next step** – The Cypriot Presidency will organize an extraordinary summit focused on Mediterranean countries. The EU will also work with Cyprus to speed up the approval of important trade agreements, including those with Mexico and other partners, aiming to open new opportunities for businesses.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Cyprus is playing a key role in helping the EU strengthen trade agreements and economic security with countries around the world.
articles.personality_title_fr: Chypre soutient les efforts commerciaux de l’UE pour renforcer la sécurité et les partenariats mondiaux
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – L’Union européenne (UE) négocie des accords commerciaux avec différents pays pour aider les entreprises et améliorer la sécurité économique. La présidence chypriote du Conseil de l’UE est un rôle de leadership que Chypre assume pendant six mois pour guider les décisions de l’UE.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Lors d’une visite à Chypre, Maroš Šefčovič, commissaire européen au Commerce et à la Sécurité économique, a salué le soutien de Chypre à la politique commerciale de l’UE. Lors d’une réunion à Limassol, Chypre a accepté d’aider la Commission européenne (CE) à atteindre des objectifs commerciaux importants, notamment la finalisation d’accords avec Mercosur (un groupe de pays sud-américains), l’Inde, les pays du Golfe et le Mexique.

**Impact** – Cette coopération est importante car elle vise à réduire les barrières commerciales et à renforcer la sécurité économique des pays de l’UE. En travaillant étroitement avec Chypre, l’UE espère créer des relations commerciales plus sûres et plus solides pour permettre aux entreprises européennes de se développer et de trouver de nouveaux partenaires. Le sommet prévu en avril réunira des dirigeants de la région méditerranéenne pour discuter du commerce, de la sécurité et de la migration, montrant un effort large pour renforcer les liens au-delà de l’Europe.

**Prochaine étape** – La présidence chypriote organisera un sommet extraordinaire axé sur les pays méditerranéens. L’UE travaillera aussi avec Chypre pour accélérer l’approbation d’accords commerciaux importants, notamment avec le Mexique et d’autres partenaires, afin d’ouvrir de nouvelles opportunités pour les entreprises.

**En résumé** – Chypre joue un rôle clé pour aider l’UE à renforcer ses accords commerciaux et sa sécurité économique avec des pays du monde entier.
articles.personality_title_es: Chipre apoya los esfuerzos comerciales de la UE para fortalecer la seguridad y las asociaciones globales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La Unión Europea (UE) trabaja con diferentes países para crear acuerdos comerciales que ayuden a las empresas y mejoren la seguridad económica. La Presidencia chipriota del Consejo de la UE es un papel de liderazgo que Chipre asume por seis meses para guiar las decisiones de la UE.

**Qué pasó** – Durante una visita a Chipre, Maroš Šefčovič, Comisario de la UE para Comercio y Seguridad Económica, elogió a Chipre por apoyar las políticas comerciales de la UE. En una reunión en Limassol, Chipre acordó ayudar a la Comisión Europea (CE) con objetivos comerciales importantes, como finalizar acuerdos con Mercosur (un grupo de países sudamericanos), India, los países del Golfo y México.

**Impacto** – Esta cooperación es importante porque busca reducir las barreras comerciales y mejorar la seguridad económica para los países de la UE. Al trabajar de cerca con Chipre, la UE espera crear relaciones comerciales más seguras y fuertes que permitan a las empresas europeas crecer y conectarse con nuevos socios. La cumbre prevista para abril reunirá a líderes de la región mediterránea para hablar sobre comercio, seguridad y migración, mostrando un esfuerzo amplio para fortalecer vínculos más allá de Europa.

**Próximo paso** – La Presidencia chipriota organizará una cumbre extraordinaria centrada en los países mediterráneos. La UE también trabajará con Chipre para acelerar la aprobación de importantes acuerdos comerciales, incluidos los de México y otros socios, con el objetivo de abrir nuevas oportunidades para las empresas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Chipre juega un papel clave ayudando a la UE a fortalecer sus acuerdos comerciales y la seguridad económica con países de todo el mundo.
